clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Plasma Catecholamine Concentration During Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Stress Hormone Concentration During the Resection of Pheochromocytoma. Comparison of Surgeon - Anesthesiologist - Patient

brief_summary.textblock: Stress during surgery leads to significant increase in plasma catecholamine concentrations in surgeons, anesthesiologists, and patients.

detailed_description.textblock: Hypothesis: Resection of pheochromocytomas can lead to more than normal stress in surgeons and because of abrupt hemodynamic changes in patients as well in anesthesiologists. Measurements of catecholamine concentrations at baseline, prior to surgery during and after surgery, are to be performed to test this hypothesis.

arm_group.description: To detect the degree of intraoperative stress, venous blod will be drawn from one surgeon during 8 pheochromocytoma resections.
To detect the degree of intraoperative stress, venous blood will be drawn from one anesthesiologist during 8 pheochromocytoma resections.
Venous blood will be drawn from 8 patients with pheochromocytoma during tumor resection.

biospec_descr.textblock: Venous blood will be drawn from the surgeon, anesthesiologist and from 8 patients to determine plasma catecholamine concentrations. Only plasma will be used for measurements.

study_pop.textblock: The population consists of 8 patients with pheochromocytoma scheduled for tumor resection, one surgeon (with the experience of more than 50 pheochromocytoma resections) and one anesthesiologist (with the experience of more than 50 pheochromocytoma resections).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: Patients with pheochromocytoma (Older than 18 years) -
Exclusion Criteria: Patients younger than 18 years. Conservative treatment.
